abstract_summ: This model provides a stylized mathematical framework that can shed light on the role of different containment measures in mitigating and suppressing the spread of an epidemics such as COVID-19.An actively controlled Susceptible-Infected-Susceptible (actSIS) contagion model is presented for studying epidemic dynamics with continuous-time feedback control of infection rates.Our model brings an advantage of building various control strategies to minimize the effect of the epidemic and can be applied to modeling the recent COVID-19 outbreak.We find that not all kernels are able to push the epidemic dynamics below the epidemic threshold, with some containment measures only able to reduce the rate of the exponential growth of new infected individuals.We show that the peak time $t_P$ and the entire time span $t_E$ could have been reduced by a factor $0.9 \le 1/\lambda\le 0.34$ with containment measures focused on increasing $\beta$ instead of reducing $\alpha$.The purpose of this work is to make a case for epidemiological models with fractional exponent in the contribution of sub-populations to the transmission rate.Our model is an extension of the SIQR (susceptible-infected-quarantine-recovered) and SIRP (susceptible-infected-recovered-pathogen) models used earlier to describe various scenarios of epidemic spread.
title_summ: Control with uncertain data of socially structured compartmental epidemic modelsLattice Model of Mitigated EpidemicComparison of epidemic control strategies using agent-based simulationsEpidemiological model with anomalous kinetics - The Covid-19 pandemicsModeling and Controlling the Spread of Epidemic with Various Social and Economic ScenariosEpidemics with containment measuresActive Control and Sustained Oscillations in actSIS Epidemic DynamicsAttainment of Herd Immunity: Mathematical Modelling of Survival RateOn the effectiveness of imposing restrictive measures in a graded Self-Organized Criticality epidemic spread modelThe case of COVID-19How to reduce epidemic peaks keeping under control the time-span of the epidemicFractional SIR Epidemiological ModelsA Brief Theory of Epidemic KineticsEpidemic modeling and control of HIV/AIDS dynamics in populations under external interactions: A worldwide challengeSpeed and strength of an epidemic interventionHow to reduce epidemic peaks keeping under control the time-span of the epidemicDynamics in a simple evolutionary-epidemiological model for the evolution of an initial asymptomatic infection stage.
title_abstract_phrases: This model provides a stylized mathematical framework that can shed light on the role of different containment measures in mitigating and suppressing the spread of an epidemics such as COVID-19.Active Control and Sustained Oscillations in actSIS Epidemic DynamicsAn actively controlled Susceptible-Infected-Susceptible (actSIS) contagion model is presented for studying epidemic dynamics with continuous-time feedback control of infection rates.Our model brings an advantage of building various control strategies to minimize the effect of the epidemic and can be applied to modeling the recent COVID-19 outbreak.We find that not all kernels are able to push the epidemic dynamics below the epidemic threshold, with some containment measures only able to reduce the rate of the exponential growth of new infected individuals.Our model is an extension of the SIQR (susceptible-infected-quarantine-recovered) and SIRP (susceptible-infected-recovered-pathogen) models used earlier to describe various scenarios of epidemic spread.The model used is a recently introduced one, which describes this epidemic spread considering two compartments of susceptible people, distinguished by the level of attention with respect to the virus transmission, one of the infected individuals not aware of their status, and two classes of patients, divided according to the level of infection.
